questions.question: Sound is produced by vibrating objects.
questions.explanation: Sound is always produced when objects vibrate, creating disturbances in the surrounding medium.

questions.question: Sound can travel through vacuum.
questions.explanation: Sound requires a material medium (solid, liquid, or gas) to travel. It cannot propagate through vacuum.

questions.question: Sound waves are transverse waves.
questions.explanation: Sound waves are longitudinal waves where particles vibrate parallel to the direction of wave propagation.

questions.question: Sound travels faster in solids than in gases.
questions.explanation: Particles in solids are closely packed, allowing faster transmission of vibrations.

questions.question: The speed of sound in air is approximately 340 m/s.
questions.explanation: At room temperature (about 20°C), sound travels at approximately 340 m/s in air.

questions.question: Loudness depends on the frequency of sound.
questions.explanation: Loudness depends on amplitude, not frequency. Frequency determines pitch.

questions.question: Pitch depends on the frequency of sound.
questions.explanation: Higher frequency produces higher pitch (shriller sound).

questions.question: The human hearing range is 20 Hz to 20,000 Hz.
questions.explanation: Humans can hear sounds in the frequency range of 20 Hz to 20,000 Hz (20 kHz).

questions.question: Ultrasonic sounds have frequency below 20 Hz.
questions.explanation: Ultrasonic sounds have frequency above 20,000 Hz. Sounds below 20 Hz are called infrasonic.

questions.question: Bats use ultrasonic sounds for navigation.
questions.explanation: Bats emit ultrasonic sounds and use echolocation to navigate and locate prey in the dark.

questions.question: Elephants can produce infrasonic sounds.
questions.explanation: Elephants produce infrasonic sounds (below 20 Hz) to communicate over long distances.

questions.question: An echo is produced when sound is absorbed by a surface.
questions.explanation: Echo is produced when sound is reflected from a surface, not absorbed.

questions.question: For an echo to be heard, the minimum distance to the reflecting surface must be 17 metres.
questions.explanation: This ensures a time gap of at least 0.1 seconds between original sound and echo.

questions.question: SONAR uses ultrasonic waves.
questions.explanation: SONAR (Sound Navigation and Ranging) uses ultrasonic waves to detect underwater objects.

questions.question: The larynx is also known as the voice box.
questions.explanation: The larynx, located at the top of the windpipe, contains the vocal cords and is called the voice box.

questions.question: Frequency and time period are directly proportional.
questions.explanation: Frequency and time period are inversely proportional (reciprocals): f = 1/T.

questions.question: The SI unit of frequency is Hertz.
questions.explanation: Hertz (Hz) is the SI unit of frequency, where 1 Hz = 1 oscillation per second.

questions.question: Wavelength is represented by the Greek letter alpha.
questions.explanation: Wavelength is represented by the Greek letter lambda (λ), not alpha.

questions.question: Sound travels faster in water than in air.
questions.explanation: Sound travels at about 1500 m/s in water, compared to 340 m/s in air.

questions.question: The speed of sound decreases with increase in temperature.
questions.explanation: Speed of sound increases with temperature because molecules move faster at higher temperatures.

questions.question: Compression is a region of high pressure in a sound wave.
questions.explanation: At compression, particles are crowded together, creating high pressure.

questions.question: A guitar is a percussion instrument.
questions.explanation: Guitar is a stringed instrument. Drums and tabla are percussion instruments.

questions.question: In a flute, sound is produced by vibrating air column.
questions.explanation: Flute is a wind instrument where sound is produced by the vibration of air column inside.

questions.question: Loudness is measured in Hertz.
questions.explanation: Loudness is measured in decibels (dB). Hertz is the unit of frequency.

questions.question: Timbre helps us distinguish between different voices.
questions.explanation: Timbre (quality) allows us to identify different voices or instruments even with same pitch and loudness.

questions.question: Sound waves can travel through the moon's surface.
questions.explanation: The moon has no atmosphere (vacuum), so sound cannot travel on the moon.

questions.question: Light travels slower than sound.
questions.explanation: Light travels at 3 × 10^8 m/s, much faster than sound at 340 m/s.

questions.question: We see lightning before hearing thunder.
questions.explanation: Light travels faster than sound, so we see lightning before hearing the thunder.

questions.question: Ultrasound can be used to scan internal organs during pregnancy.
questions.explanation: Ultrasound scanning (sonography) safely creates images of internal organs and the baby during pregnancy.

questions.question: Reverberation is the same as echo.
questions.explanation: Echo is a single reflection heard separately; reverberation is multiple reflections creating prolonged sound.

questions.question: Sound absorbing materials increase echo in a room.
questions.explanation: Sound absorbing materials reduce echo and reverberation by absorbing sound instead of reflecting it.

questions.question: A stethoscope works on the principle of multiple reflection of sound.
questions.explanation: Sound is reflected multiple times through the tube of a stethoscope to reach the doctor's ears.

questions.question: Higher frequency sounds have longer wavelength.
questions.explanation: At constant speed, higher frequency means shorter wavelength (v = f × λ).

questions.question: Sound carries energy without carrying matter.
questions.explanation: Sound waves transfer energy through particle vibrations without actual transfer of matter.

questions.question: Men's voices are usually higher pitched than women's voices.
questions.explanation: Men have longer, thicker vocal cords that vibrate slower, producing lower-pitched (deeper) voices.

questions.question: The persistence of hearing in humans is about 0.1 seconds.
questions.explanation: Human ear retains sensation of sound for about 0.1 seconds (persistence of hearing).

questions.question: Dolphins can produce and hear ultrasonic sounds.
questions.explanation: Dolphins use ultrasonic sounds for echolocation to navigate and hunt underwater.

questions.question: Earthquakes produce ultrasonic waves.
questions.explanation: Earthquakes produce infrasonic waves (below 20 Hz), not ultrasonic waves.

questions.question: A dog whistle produces sounds that humans cannot hear.
questions.explanation: Dog whistles produce ultrasonic sounds above 20,000 Hz that dogs can hear but humans cannot.

questions.question: Lithotripsy uses ultrasound to break kidney stones.
questions.explanation: Lithotripsy uses high-intensity ultrasound waves to shatter kidney stones into smaller pieces.

questions.question: Amplitude determines the pitch of a sound.
questions.explanation: Amplitude determines loudness, not pitch. Frequency determines pitch.

questions.question: The speed of sound in steel is greater than in water.
questions.explanation: Sound travels at about 5000 m/s in steel compared to 1500 m/s in water.

questions.question: In longitudinal waves, particles move perpendicular to wave direction.
questions.explanation: In longitudinal waves, particles move parallel (back and forth) to the direction of wave propagation.

questions.question: The eardrum vibrates when sound enters the ear.
questions.explanation: Sound waves cause the eardrum (tympanic membrane) to vibrate, starting the hearing process.

questions.question: Noise pollution can cause hearing loss.
questions.explanation: Prolonged exposure to loud sounds (above 80 dB) can damage hearing.

questions.question: Shorter strings on a guitar produce lower pitch.
questions.explanation: Shorter strings vibrate faster, producing higher frequency and higher pitch sounds.

questions.question: Tightening a string increases its pitch.
questions.explanation: Tighter strings vibrate faster, increasing frequency and thus increasing pitch.

questions.question: Compression and rarefaction alternate in a sound wave.
questions.explanation: Sound waves consist of alternating regions of compression (high pressure) and rarefaction (low pressure).

questions.question: Megaphones work by absorbing sound.
questions.explanation: Megaphones work by multiple reflections of sound, directing it in a specific direction.

questions.question: Ultrasound can detect cracks in metal structures.
questions.explanation: Ultrasound waves reflect from internal cracks, helping detect flaws in metal structures.
